questions.name: Incompressible flows
questions.statement: Which of the following sets of equations represent (s) possible three-dimensional incompressible flow cases?
options: u = xyzt, v = −xyzt^2, w = z^2 (xt^2 − yt)
Straining flow given in Sheet #3, Q3.2, i.e. u = 1 + αx, v = −αy

questions.name: Steady incompressible flow
questions.statement: The x component of velocity in a steady incompressible flow field in the xy plane is u = A exp(x/b) cos(y/b), where A and b are two constants. Find the y component of velocity for this flow field.

questions.name: Steady incompressible boundary layer
questions.statement: A useful approximation for the x component of velocity in an incompressible laminar boundary layer is a sinusoidal variation from u = 0 at the wall (y = 0) to the free stream velocity, U, at the edge of theboundary layer (y = δ). The equation for the profile is u = U sin[πy/(2δ)], where δ = c√x and c is aconstant. Sketch the boundary layer in the xy plane. Plot u/U and v/U versus y/δ

questions.name: Gas expanding in a cylinder
questions.statement: A gas-filled pneumatic strut in an automobile suspension system behaves like a piston-cylinder apparatus. At one instant when the piston is L = 0.15 m away from the closed end of the cylinder, the gas density is uniform at ρ = 18 kg/m3 and the piston begins to move away from the closed end at U = 12 m/s. The gas velocity is one-dimensional and proportional to distance from the closed end; it varies linearly from zero at the end to u = U at the piston. The density field at any instant in time is uniform in space.
sections: Obtain an expression for the average density as a function of time
Evaluate the rate of change of gas density at t = 0
Graph density as a function of time.

questions.name: Simplifying the Euler Equations
questions.statement: [Not actually part of this sheet, but here as an example] Simplify the Euler equations in the following senarios,
sections: One Dimentional, ie all fileds have only one component, including velociy and pressure.
